table_items.text: Initial draft created to replace the following policies: MEHT 14040 ICT Change Control Policy BTUH IM/PO/00021 IT Change Management

data.text: Table of Contents
Definitions and Terminology ..............................
Quality Impact Assessment (QIA) ..........................
Equality Impact Assessment (EIA) ........................ 12 Appendix 1, Quality Impact Assessment   13 Appendix 2, Equality Impact Assessment (EIA)
Introduction
The Trust recognises the need to ensure that a robust change control and management is maintained in relation to all aspects of Digital Services.
This policy has been written in conjunction with current Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) framework in order to ensure that services are aligned with the needs of the business.

The aim of this policy is to ensure that the measures that will be taken to protect the systems, services and data that are used by the organisation. This document also provides a summary of the process that is required in relation to Change Management.
Scope

This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
This policy applies to any Trust end-user computing devices which includes, but is not limited to PCs, laptops, hand-held mobile devices (iPads, iPods etc), analyser interfaces and kiosks.

This policy refers to changes deemed to be normal, or business as usual (BAU) change; ie, any work that is project based or part of scheduled infrastructure maintenance will be considered as a normal or BAU change. Any change that necessitates emergency action to resolve an existing high priority incident or major incident will not be subjected to this policy.
Definitions and Terminology

table_items.text: This should be in reference to the individual Trust that the employee is employed by. Trusts refereed to include Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
Responsibility for an decisions and actions of an entity
Anything that has a value to the Trust
An asset being accessible and usable with valid authentication
Action of processes and procedures that ensure continued business operations usually associate to risk
Information not shared or disclosed to authorised users
Cyber security is a term used to describe technologies, processes and controls that are implemented to protect systems, networks and data from cyber-attacks.
Data or knowledge that has value to the Trust
Information Asset Administrator - operational managers responsible for maintaining the integrity of one or more information assets, managing information risks locally.
Senior Manager who is responsible for managing information assets to comply with statutory obligations such as FOI, GDPR etc.
Protecting the confidentiality, loss, accidental disclosure of Information Asset(s) from unauthorised person(s)/ organisations(s)
One or more unwanted or unexpected information security issues that result in the probability of compromising business operations and Information Security
Protection of the accuracy and completeness of an Information Asset
Information Technology Infrastructure Library framework is a set of detailed practices for IT service management (ITSM) that focuses on aligning IT services with the needs of business.
Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed Matrix is a visual tool used to highlight roles and responsibilities relating to a Configuration Item, function or process.

data.text: Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1 Digital Services Governance Group – to review policies and recommend for group approval.
4.1.2 Information Governance Group – to review any instances of non-compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3 Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 The Chief Executive as the Trust's Accountable Officer has ultimate responsibility for compliance with legal requirements and achievement of standards of best practice and will ensure:
Appropriate delegation of risk management and confidentiality management functions to a Director or equivalent;
Adequate resources to support effective information governance;
Submission of the annual Data Security and Protection Toolkit compliance self- assessment
4.2.2 Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.3 Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of IT Security Policies and management of IT Infrastructure.
4.2.4 Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that appropriate staffs are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
Determining which individuals are to be given authority to access specific information systems. The level of access to specific systems should be on a job function need, independent of status;

Ensuring that the relevant IAA's/user system managers are advised immediately about staff changes affecting computer access (e.g. job function changes/leaving department or organisation) so that passwords may be withdrawn/deleted.
4.2.5 Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
4.2.6 Information Asset Owners (IAO)
Usually the Clinical Directorate Director (CD) or Divisional Manager who are responsible for;

Take ownership of their local asset control, risk assessment and management processes for the information assets they own. This includes the identification, review and prioritisation of perceived risks and oversight of actions to mitigate those risks.
Ensure that this policy is adhered to at all times in relation to the management of any systems upgrades or implementations within their control.
To supervise and delegate tasks to the IAA.
4.2.7 Information Asset Administrators (IAA)

The IAA is an operational member of staff with a high level of working knowledge of the business functions of the area and use of the information assets, usually department heads, system super-users or system managers. The IAA's primary role is to support the IAO to fulfil their responsibilities. Detailed responsibilities will be in agreement with the IAO, but are likely to include:
Maintenance of details and risk assessments relating to their nominated Information Assets
Recognising new information handling requirements (e.g. a new type of information arises) and that the IAO is consulted over appropriate procedures
– e.g. completing/updating data flow mapping.
Recognising potential or actual security incidents and consulting with the IAO
Reporting to the IAO on current state of local information handling
Ensuring that local information handling constraints (e.g. limits on who can have access to the assets) are applied, referring any difficulties to the IAO.
Responsible for adhering to this policy at all times in relation to the management of any systems upgrades or implementations within their control.
4.2.8 Change Manager

The Change Manager is a member of the Digital Services who responsible for the overall quality of the Change Management process. He/she is the main coordinator of the Change Advisory Board (CAB) (see section 5.3 for further information) and is the focal point regarding changes for both the customer and the IT organization.
4.2.9 Service Owner
The Service Owner is responsible for delivering a particular service and who will lead a team of technical specialists or an internal support unit.
Policy Requirements
Triggers for a Normal Change

5.1.1 A Request for Change (RFC) can be triggered at any point throughout the lifecycle of a service. Many factors can trigger a service to be changed and may involve interaction with not only the business, but also with the relevant suppliers of a service to ensure a successful implementation.

5.1.2 Changes may be required for many reasons such as legislation changes, technology innovation, application or operating system upgrades or patches, changes to one or more services such as increase in capacity, Service Portfolio amendments, Disaster Recovery strategy changes or to decommission a service/hardware.

5.1.3 A Request for Change may come from different sources, however any requests that have been raised externally to the IT department must be raised via the IT Service Desk. The groups of people who are authorised to raise a new Request for Change through the IT Service Desk are:
System Managers
Technical specialists
Directors
Stakeholders
General Managers
Project Managers
Supplier / Vendor
Emergency Requests for Change

5.2.1 Where changes are required that are urgent or critical in nature, these can be approved via emergency change control with approval the Head of Digital Services, IT Operations Manager and/or the appropriate service lead ie Infrastructure or systems owners, outside to the standard notice period and CAB meetings.
5.2.2 All recent approved emergency change controls will be reviewed during the next CAB and a formal change request will be completed outlining the changes undertaken and the reasons etc.
The Change Advisory Board (CAB)
5.3.1 The CAB board meet on a weekly basis to review and monitor all Normal Changes.
5.3.2 The Change Manager is responsible for having the change assessed, but the Service Manager and Service Owner still have the final accountability for the service.

5.3.3 It may be necessary to include additional members of staff such as stakeholders and technical specialists at the CAB meeting to provide specialist knowledge and expertise on the subject. The stakeholders will be asked to provide information during the CAB meeting as this would influence the approval of the Change request.

5.3.4 CAB will provide a monthly summary report of changes to the appropriate review group, this will include more detailed information of those changes undertaken but were unsuccessful or breached its original planned outage window.
RACI (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed) Matrix
5.4.1  A RACI matrix model is a visual tool used to highlight roles and responsibilities relating to a Configuration Item, function or process.
Key: Responsible, Accountable, Informed, Consulted
Proposing a Request for Change (RFC)

5.5.1 In order to fully understand the work that is required for a proposed Request for Change, preparation work must be completed and presented to the C.A.B for all new Request for Changes. The scale of work required would determine the amount of detail required for each point listed below. These questions and pieces of information will be asked for by the Change Manager. If a suitable answer is not provided for each point in the checklist, the Request for Change may be rejected.
5.5.2 The seven R's of a Request for Change need to be considered for each Change raised:
5.5.3 In addition to the points raised above, the following information will also need to be prepared for review by the CAB:

5.5.4 A change control request, outlining the change required, work completed, testing undertaken etc, must be completed and submitted to the CAB, via the Service Desk system, for consideration no less than 1 week prior to the planned change.

5.5.5 For major, organisational affecting changes such as network/telephony or email maintenance, a minimum of 4weeks notice is required in order to fully consider the implications of the change and to engage with the Trust Emergency Planning Officer and relevant operational staff groups.
5.5.6 The change request forms will be considered by the CAB, the change requestor/third party supplier may be requested to attend the CAB in order provide further information or assurances.

5.5.7 The CAB may deny a change request for reasons including, but not limited to; inadequate planning and/or testing has taken place, insufficient rollback plans or if the timing of the change will negatively impact a key business process such as year- end accounting or clinical activity or if adequate resources are not readily available. A change may also be declined if the relevant user/customer interaction and agreement is not sort in advance of the change.
5.5.8 The outcome of the change request will be formally communicated back to the original requestor following the CAB meeting.
5.5.9 For further guidance please refer to the current Change Control process.
Reviewing the Effectiveness of Completed Changes

5.6.1 The changes that have taken place the previous week, both planned and emergency changes, will be reviewed at start of every CAB in order to capture any issues that arose and ensure that the change has been completed.

5.6.2 If any changes undertaken were identified as being required to rolled back or resulted in major unexpected issues a review will be undertaken to determine the underlying issue to ensure lessons are learnt and feedback into the process for future reference.
5.6.3 All recent approved emergency change controls will be reviewed during the next CCAB and a formal change request will be completed outlining the changes undertaken and the reasons etc.
Unplanned Outages

5.7.1  Any unplanned outages or disruptions to services, not part of any planed changes are not covered by this policy and will be managed through the completion of an incident and outage report which is then reviewed by the Incident & Outage review group.
Training Requirements
All staff are required to complete IG training as part of their annual mandatory training obligations.
If there are any concerns regarding the content or implication of this policy they should be directed to the IT Service Desk.
Monitoring & Audit
In addition to the legal liabilities outlined above, staff who breach any of the terms of this policy may be subject to disciplinary action.
Compliance to this policy will be monitored as follows:

table_items.text: Responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Effectiveness of the planning and delivery of changes

The following legislation will also apply to this policy (due to continual changes in legislation this list is not exhaustive):
Access to Health Records 1990
Access to Medical Reports Act 1988
Computer Misuse Act 1990
Data Protection (Processing of Sensitive Personal Data) Order 2000.
Electronic Communications Act 2000
Freedom of Information Act 2000
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
Health & Social Care Act 2001

Appendix 1, Quality Impact Assessment
Title of document being impact-assessed: Change Management Policy

table_items.text: 1.1. What evidence has been used to develop this proposal (e.g. NICE, NCEPOD, audit, patient or staff surveys?)
IG Toolkit General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Best Practice ITIL v3
1.2. What changes does this proposal make to the care pathway?
Supports the robust delivery of IT services and systems
1.3. Describe the positive impact on: Patient safety Clinical effectiveness Patient experience
Ensures that service interruptions resulting from planned changes are reduced by following structured and robust change management processes N/A
1.4. What current or new clinical outcome measures will monitor these benefits?

2.1. Describe how the impact of the change has been considered in relation to: Infection Prevention and Control Safeguarding vulnerable adults/ children Current quality indicators Quality Account priorities Patients/ carers/ members of the public Promoting self-care for people with long-term conditions Tackling health inequalities
Supports compliance to IG Toolkit, General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Best Practice and ISO standards
2.2. How will you monitor the impact of this proposal? (Provide details of how this will be done, by whom, and when)
Staff not engaging with the defined policy
Persons who identified non- compliance to defined policy
Regular monitoring reports made available for review
Incident & Outage review meeting and/or Digital Services Governance Meetings
